text:
Hi Chris, I was working on the the Neural DE stuff you suggested by splitting the datapoints and training on smaller intervals. I tried a quite a few combinations of different loss functions, using different sizes of NNs etc. But none of them seem to work in "general".
For example, if we need our NN to recognize the function y = x*(sin(3x)), I couldn't fit the NN's predictions to the actual values and am always getting stuck in some local minima for this function. Do you have any suggestions?

elements.text:
Hi Chris, I was working on the the Neural DE stuff you suggested by splitting the datapoints and training on smaller intervals. I tried a quite a few combinations of different loss functions, using different sizes of NNs etc. But none of them seem to work in "general".
For example, if we need our NN to recognize the function y = x*(sin(3x)), I couldn't fit the NN's predictions to the actual values and am always getting stuck in some local minima for this function. Do you have any suggestions?

text: Also I noted some of my observations, let me know if I should post them here?:sweat_smile:

So should I make a tutorial on just one example for now? The function in the example is the same as in this link: <https://diffeqflux.sciml.ai/dev/examples/local_minima/>
It worked best when I divided the dataset into groups of 6.

text: I was about to say "do multiple shooting" as i found it to be much more succesfull when doing parameter estimation on periodic systems (such as Lottka-Voltera equation), compared to restarts and global optimizations.
I've just been leaving it as a GSoC project :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I've just been leaving it as a GSoC project

text: One problem with growing it over time is that dynamics which become relevant later might become unable to be found, due to getting stuck in a local minima early.
